I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/05/half-life.html
(As a note: I have played this game longer than the listed time before I had Steam.)

What sets this game apart?
Half-Life was an influential milestone in gaming and has been considered one of the best games of all time by various magazines and critics. The main reasons for its acclaim and success deal with the way the game is presented, completely through the eyes of its protagonist, who is unseen and unheard except for his hands. This full immersion into Gordon Freeman's perspective means that there are no virtually no cut scenes or text boxes, leaving the player in control and learning the story through observation and conversation. Progression through the game is often not completely linear, featuring puzzles and exploration that had not been featured in earlier first-person shooters. Half-Life also utilizes aspects from the survival horror genre, both atmospheric and mechanical, from jump scenes to limited ammunition. Half-Life was a unique entity on the first-person shooter market, and a milestone for PC gaming in general. In addition to its contributions as its own entity, several expansions were released and Valve Software encouraged outside developers to create third-party mods.

What is the difficulty factor?
The introduction to the game is amazing in its simplicity. To teach you how to move about and to introduce you to the Black Mesa complex, the game begins with Gordon Freeman is running late for work and you must hurry to the lab. From here, new information is displayed as it becomes necessary, although anyone familiar with PC first-person shooters should be able to pick things up quickly.

As a whole, Half-Life tends to be a fairly difficult game, however the difficulty rarely comes from the same place as first-person shooters that came before it. The puzzles and three-dimensional platforming make up the core of the game, and the survival horror elements like limited ammunition and unique enemy AI and detection make Half-Life a thinking game. Rushing and running and gunning will be less successful than a patient and thoughtful strategy.

Does it use media effectively?
Half-Life looks great and it has aged fairly well. The environments are detailed and diverse, exploring the full range of the Black Mesa complex, inside and out. The creatures and alien weapons are creative, drawing on similar creatures from science fiction and putting a unique twist on them. The horror aspects of the game are well set up with plenty of jump scenes and tense moments. The soundtrack helps add to the suspense at times, while adding to the adrenaline of the actions scenes at others. The voice acting left a bit to be desired, even when the game came out, but the croaking computerized voice is a recognizable relic of Half-Life that you won't soon forget.

Best moment in the game?
Half-Life has a lot of great moments, several of which involve blowing up helicopters, trains, or giant monsters. Half-Life also has a lot of great quiet moments, even the train ride to work at the beginning of the game is impressive in its own way. When I sat down to think about the best moment in the game, for me, one scene popped immediately to my mind. During the chapter Apprehension, you encounter your first Ichthyosaur, a giant fish rivaled only by the Boss Bass in Mario 3 in virtual-fish-frustration. The Ichthyosaur grabs a scientist in a flash when you first enter his domain, and soon you find yourself dangling over his pond in a cage, forced to confront the force of nature before you run out of oxygen. I remember this sequence as the one that made me jump the most during my first play through, and it holds up now. It is also when you receive the crossbow, and I'm a bit of a sucker for sniping weapons, but the scene is still really memorable with that fact aside.

Who needs to play this game?
You mean you haven't played this game? Shame on you! Half-Life is a classic game and is often considered among the best in the history of gaming. Even 15 years later, it holds up extremely well. Even if you are not normally a fan of first-person shooters, this is not the action dredged game that you might expect; it has its moments, but they do not define the game. It plays closer to a faster paced survival horror game, full of atmosphere and puzzles and monsters. Half-Life is available on Steam and is frequently on sale during their sales. If you pick it up, I would highly suggest getting the pack that includes Opposing Force and Blue Shift, the two expansion games released by Valve.

It's 1998 and you're playing a new game. You're riding in some type of a train through these bottomless dark halls filled with pipes, and windows with scientists, some robots and a strange guy in a blue suit. All this seems to be part of some huge underground complex.

Suddenly this game interacts with you, telling you that you're late for some kind of experiment. This seems to be important so youre trying to get there. You get your HEV suit and venture deeper into Black Mesa. Something feels a miss as your noticing system errors and a computer explosion, not to mention that radioactive leak you saw while riding the train. But everyone keeps telling you that everything is properly fine. So you go ahead with the experiment and *BOOM* *CRASH*

And now you're no longer that guy sitting in front of a computer playing some new video game. You're Gordon Freeman. A new employee of the Black Mesa Research Facility with a Ph.D in Theoretical Physics, who has now witnessed a resonance cascade, causing extraterristial beings to cross over from somewhere else. Now you most escape this terrible catastrophe!

El mejor videojuego de disparos en primera persona. Con una extensísima historia y una gran gama de armas debes sobrevivir a lo largo de las instalaciones de Black Mesa (y de otro mundo). Muy recomendado, y si no tienes prisa en comprarlo, espera a las rebajas de invierno o de verano.

You're looking for a badass old-school first person shooting game? well it's your lucky day! HALF-LIFE has all elements that a game needs to be a BADASS! It's a refined game with an interesting story,gameplay,and even "puzzles" in some levels that may require some thinking and it also has a multi-player that still works!

Even though its clear that the game is old, the gameplay itself hasn't aged one bit. It's both difficult and challenging but in a refreshing way. Worth whatever you might pay for it, this game is one of the best ever made.

I never really avidly played Half-Life until I got my hands on a mod called "Brutal Half-Life."
After completing the mod that opened my eyes to just how much I enjoy this game.
Albeit this isn't exactly Brutal Half-Life, but if it wasn't for Half-Life we wouldn't have Valve games or even Steam for that matter.
This is one of those games that has an exceeding amount of replayability, especially for someone who goes for speedruns in this game.



So that's out of the way here's what you need to know:

You start out as a character named Gordon Freeman: the protagonist and scientist that's majorly responsible for the events that plays out.

The prologue is slow but eerie, but once the introduction is done you jump straight into the action.

And it's not just about action; there's puzzles and methodical planning when you play this.

When you reach to the hard difficulty it really is a challenge to put forth into this game.

And there's no definitive way to play it, besides the linear storyline.

I.E. there's always an option to either cooperate with your fellow scientists/comrades or you can go on a complete killing spree.

Albeit towards the end of the game it's more straight foward.

The story in this game is dark, gritty, and beautifully told through an unbroken first-person narrative.

If you're interested in the combat side of things, the arsenal of weapons is far from few.
You have weapons such as the classic double-pump shotgun, to the overpowered Gluon gun, to the oddly unique Hornet gun when things get dire.

All in all: This is a master-piece.

And if you don't enjoy the retro and outdated graphics of 1998 then there's a third-party developed, graphically  enhanced, and extended version of this game called [b]Black Mesa.[/b]

This game is dirt cheap compared to today's standards so you bet your sweet-ass you should get a copy of this game, so you can show all your blood thirsty foes who's the king!
вспомни деЦтво :)

This game is infinitely ahead of its time. Once you've played a few hours of it, you'll be stunned to learn that it was released in 1998. It combines pretty much EVERYTHING a game needs - fun gameplay, intriguing story, challenging "puzzles", unique enemies, and a kick-ass finale boss battle. Buy this game, and enter Gaben's greatest masterpiece!

[h1]Un de ces jeux qui ont marqué leur époque.[/h1]

De part ses qualités et la nouveauté de son concept en 1998, un jeu comme Half-Life était une vraie prise de risque pour Valve. Son succès incontestable ouvra la voie à ce qui est malheureusement devenu une solution de facilité pour la plupart des grosses boîtes d'aujourd'hui : Privilégier l'histoire au détriment d'un gameplay bien huilé. Heureusement des jeux capables de concilier les deux existent.

J'ai bien entendu apprécié le début du jeu. Mais ça s'est un peu gâté par la suite à cause des mouvements de Freeman. Se bloquer dans un mur tout plat, buter dans les marches d'escaliers, mourir parce qu'on a toucher le mur dans la cage d'ascenseur... (╬ Ò ‸ Ó)

Et ne me dite surtout pas : [i]"Ouais mais c'est un vieu jeu, faut être un peu clément"[/i].
Le moteur 3D de Half-Life, GoldSrc, est un dérivé du Quake Engine. Et même malgré l'âge, on bouge toujours très bien dans Quake 1.

En dehors de ce soucis, le scénario de Half-Life était déjà très bon.
Passer les 5 premières minutes dans un wagon, suivant un rail dans un sous-terrain... Vous pouvez bien vous y déplacer mais il est vide et finalement peu spacieux. Rien qu'avec cela, le ton est donné concernant votre champ de liberté.
[spoiler]Et pour le coup, la progression toute linéaire tout le long du jeu n'a rien de choquante. On pourrait même se demander si cela n'a pas justement motivé les développeurs à en faire un jeu particulièrement long pour son époque.
Et le jeu se permettra à la toute fin de reboucler avec l'introduction en vous faisant miroiter le choix de suivre ou non le fameux G-Man. Deux fins pseudo-alternatives, or il est clair que si vous voulez vivre, vous n'avez juste pas le choix.
Et pour pousser dans l'ironie, il se trouve que cette séquence a lieu dans le même wagon que l'introduction du jeu, alors qu'on avait pourtant été téléporté sur une planète extraterrestre.[/spoiler]

FPS genre started out with Id Software's Wolfenstein in 1992. 

That same company later released Doom, and for quite a while most shooters were simply tagged as Doom Clones. Games like Quake, Duke Nukem, Shadow Warrior, Star Wars Dark Forces, Unreal were among them. These games lacked narrative and had a very maze like level design. It's very different from what we have today in our shooters.

Then in 1998, came Half Life. Love it or hate it, this game is the blueprint for all the shooters that come out these days. It was among the first shooters to have narrative. To account for the narrative, it had to make the level design more linear. The game is driven by the story, so to say. Level would be build around it, having set pieces here and there.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Games from the Doom era focused on you trying to avoid the incoming projectiles that are shot at you. They focused on mobility. Since they had a very maze like level design. They also would usually have a lot of secret places, where you could get better gear or ammo. Exploration was another thing that was focused on in older fps.

Half Life on other hand played differently from earlier FPS games. Accuracy wasn't something that was a thing back then, but with Half Life it was. You had a crosshair and you could not only look at x-axis, but also move your camera up and down (y-axis). All weapons in Half Life would also feature recoil on their guns.

You would also face enemies, with guns just like you. They would have cheater like accuracy. You wouldn't be able to dodge their incoming bullets. All you will be able to do is go behind cover.

I hope you find all this familiar.

That said, Half Life did feature elements from Doom games - mostly when encountering aliens. Headcrabs for example will jump at you. Vortigons would shot a green beam with a few seconds of delay. There are some that that spit corrosive fluid. All of these are dodge-able. The game also has Grunts, which are very big bullet sponges.

When encountering normal soldiers on other hand, it will play like today's shooter. Still, there is a fair amount of both in the game.

The game still has plenty of secret places with ammo and weapons stashes, so exploration isn't completely off the table.

Finally, it features a lot of puzzle solving and platforming, which is a bit unusual for an FPS. I personally found it very frustrating.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Back in the days, there was no story in FPS games. And even if there was, it would be delivered via cutscenes. Well, Half Life changed that. Like a said, a linear level design. Along that level, they would have friendly NPCs, with whom you could interact with, and cinematic set pieces. You would do more than just "run and gun".

Half Life story may not be unique, but it's about how they deliver it, that makes it so special. No one has ever done that, up till that point. They were the first.

Also, it may not look like it, but back then it was amazing. The game didn't even come to PS1 simply because the console couldn't handle the technology involved. Valve used GldSrc, which was based on Quake's engine. It's a groundbreaking game.

The only thing i want to complain about is the sounds. It really hurt my ears.

This game consists of 18 Chapters and an Epilogue, giving you 2 choices. It's fairly long - about 15 hours.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I really like Half Life. In fact i like it more than the second game. It has elements from both pre Half Life and post Half Life. I highly recommend it to anyone.

Currently, there is a fan made remake called Black Mesa. Better graphics, but the same game. It was developed since 2004 and was released to the public by 2012. That's 8 years of hard work. It's still missing 4 levels, but they plan to add them at some point. Nevertheless, i suggest you to support them.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/362890/

Half-Life is the game that set the standards to all first person shooters, this one being more and more interesting than the rest and several titles following it for it's mysterious protagonist, Gordon Freeman, and the bleak government cover-up attempt of the Black Mesa incident. Its legacy has become more of a guideline for how first person titles should be with level designs, minor puzzles, optional companions and plot development. The game and its sequels will go down in history as the most critically acclaimed franchise of all time. If you haven't played this game, then you must.

When a game that's 15 years old manages to be as fun as a current-gen game, it's fucking good. This is good. The gameplay is your regular, pretty hard good ol' shooter, but the story and atmosphere are superb. As I've said many times before, old games are masters of ambience, and Half-Life is master of masters. The best part about it is probably the eerily mysterious g-man, who you sometimes see calmly walking around an immense base, where, for reasons unknown, hell broke loose. 

You play no part in the unleashing of hell. You are just some research assistant who is relatively new to the place and one day got caught up in this 'accident'. First you see this g-man walking around, obviously unaffected by the chaos, and you wonder what the fuck he has to do with this mess. Later the military shows up trying to kill everybody involved, and you're just trying to figure out what the hell happened. Right now I'm getting messages from the Lambda Team (no idea who they are) and I've done them some favours. I am seriously eager to meet them and shake some answers out of them. I won't spoil much more, but I think it's clear that the story is sublime. And if you've enjoyed HL2 without playing this game, get ready to re-enjoy the crap out of HL2. I was kinda playing HL2:EP2 and this through eachother, but when Alyx randomly said: 'Prepare for unforseen consequences' shivers went down every single one of my bones. Damn, getting reminded of the hellish mess that is Half Life 1 is actually scary.

This game is hard, eery, and absolutely fantastic. I am serious, you NEED to play this. Need. I have never been more sincere. Need. I would say that it is necessary for your very survival. What the hell are you still doing here? Buy the bloody game and play it now!

Za pierwszą część przygód Gordona Freemana stosunkowo trudno było mi się zabrać. Choć wersja dostępna na platformie Steam jest nieco odświeżona w stosunku do oryginału z 1998 roku, to i tak jest to tylko poprawiony pod względem tekstur i ustawień graficznych 15-letni... hit.

Gra mimo swojego wieku wciąż potrafi zaskakiwać. Wstyd mi przyznać, że miałem okazję ukończyć ją dopiero w tym roku, ale z pewnością tego nie żałuję.

Gordon Freeman to pracownik laboratorium Black Mesa umiejscowionego gdzieś na pustkowiach Nowego Meksyku. Właśnie nadszedł czas na przeprowadzenie nowego eksperymentu, który na zawsze odmieni życie zarówno Freemana, jak i reszty pracowników Black Mesa.

W wyniku nieszczęśliwego wypadku, otwarto portal pomiędzy Ziemią, a alternatywnym światem zwanym Xen. Od tej pory Freeman i pozostali pracownicy ośrodka badawczego muszą walczyć o przetrwanie i balansować pomiędzy dwoma równoległymi światami. Zagrożenie czyha nie tylko ze strony istot pozaziemskich, ale także sił opozycyjnych, których zadaniem jest schwytanie Gordona i pozbycie się wszelkich świadków...

Brzmi trochę oklepanie? Ale jakże to grywalne!

Od samego początku wiedziałem, że gram już w grę legendę, także trudno było mi jej nie rozliczać z tego tytułu. Ku mojemu(miłemu) zaskoczeniu, gra na to miano zasługuje. Mimo, iż to gra z gatunku FPS, to określenie jej mianem pierwszoosobowej strzelanki moim zdaniem trochę jej ubliża... Gra z początku przytłacza rozmiarem poziomów, które nie są prowadzone w sposób korytarzowy jak to ma miejsce np. w serii Call of Duty, mimo to, projekt poziomów stoi na tak wysokim poziomie, że zawsze wiemy, gdzie iść i co robić.

Inteligencja przeciwników jak na 1998 rok bije na głowę. Dla przykładu w grach takich jak Return to Castle Wolfenstein przeciwnicy z reguły prowadzą ostrzał z góry ustalonego miejsca. W Half-Life tak nie jest. Tutaj wrogowie(mowa głównie o nieustannie próbujących nas zabić żołnierzach) nie mają problemu z oflankowaniem nas, a kiedy mają potrzebę przeładowania broni lub nie są w stanie wytrzymać kolejnej serii z M4, lubią chować się za skrzyniami, skąd trudniej ich będzie trafić. Stworów ze świata Xen jest naprawdę dużo. Począwszy od przypominających kurczaki headcrabów, które nieustannie próbują, niczym facehugger z serii Obcy, wskoczyć nam na głowę, przez rażące piorunami Vortigaunty, po przypominające Uber Soldaty z późniejszego i wspomnianego już RtCW Alien Grunty.

Jeśli chodzi o bronie, mamy tu dostępny całkiem spory arsenał. Najbardziej kojarzony z serią łom, na początku jest niezbędny, by przetrwać, a później, jak najbardziej, wykorzystuje się go do rozwalania skrzynek z zaopatrzeniem. Oprócz tego mamy tu pistolety, wspomniany już karabin M4, a nawet bazookę, są także ściśle tajne prototypy oraz bronie wykorzystywane przez niektórych mieszkańców świata Xen.

Taki zestaw jest niezbędny do pokonania bossów, których choć nie ma zbyt wielu, to każdy z nich z pewnością stanowi wyzwanie.

Muzyka pojawia się niestety dość sporadycznie, ale tytuł radzi sobie i bez niej co najmniej dobrze. Utwory są krótkie, ale doskonale oddają klimat gier FPP z końca lat 90, a klimat ten w Half-Life jest przedni...

Podsumowując, pierwszy Half-Life, to świetna gra dla fanów Quake'a, którzy chcieliby poznać wreszcie jakąś ciekawszą historię. Fabuła gry może nie jest sztuką, ale w kinach mamy masę blockbusterów z o wiele słabszym wątkiem.

Half-Life miał ogromny wpływ na całą branżę, a jego spuściznę możemy dostrzeć we wspomnianym po raz kolejny Return to Castle Wolfenstein, a nawet gier o wiele nowszych, takich jak np. seria Dead Space.

Jeśli jeszcze nie grałeś w pierwszą część serii Half-Life, musisz dać jej szansę.

Because this game relied on shock and awe cinematics back in the day of 1998, and I havn't really taken this game seriously at all and prefer to noclip to where devs wouldn't really want players to go. This is the Raiders of the Lost Ark of video games as in its much of an art statement, but something that really needs to be experienced by anyone calling themselves a gamer, and even more crutial to 'fps players". Also a great pic for anyone who actually remembers when valve made "games" on time and didn't crowdsource jobs.

9/10. (Age is a virtue and a killer, right?)
Magnífico juego de principio a fin pese a sus años. Increíblemente entretenido, magnífica jugabilidad, una buena historia.... en fin, un juegazo.

Beats many modern shooters in many ways. Don't let the old graphics or lack of trailer turn you off, this game has aged well. Not only is this a great game but it led to the creation of many more like : Counter strike, Team Fortress and many more which are now there own titles all with future versions. If you don't want to buy this game at least get Black Mesa, a free fan-made version with updated graphics.

This Game really stands up to its reputation. The graphics are actually really good considering its age and the story and gameplay are simply on point. I highly recommend to play this game on Hard difficulty in order to get the best experience out of it. Playing on Normal Mode was fun but I felt more like an unbeatable super trained veteran marine than like a scientist just trying to survive a catastrophic scenario he accidentaly got thrown into. However, on Hard the Gaming experience changes a lot (positively):
- you are very short on ammunition making you think twice weather you simply try to rambo everything with your guns or if you take the (really lethal) risk of trying to kill stuff with your crowbar or if you actually try to sneak past certain enemies
- Aliens and Enemies in general HURT (they really do). This actually made me get scared of those Aliens. They might not (considering today's graphics standards) look scary as a 3D-Model but if they are actually able to kill you with ease you start to feel true fear if they suddenly pop up behind a corner you just walked by.
- Your playstyle becomes a lot more stealthy and thoughtful. This is actually really realistic. I mean how should a scientist with no combat experience and conditioning apart from maybe having watched the Star Wars Series take out a huge Unit of special Forces together with a bunch of invading aliens if he doesn't try to outsmart and surprise them ?
These and some other experiences I gathered are really reasons to play this game on Hard difficulty. I was actually so surprised about how much better the Game felt on Hard that I decided to play all my future games on hard difficulty without beating it on any lower difficulty anymore. 
As a result to my 30 hours journey into Half Life 1 I have to state that this is an awesome part of gaming history that everyone who calls himself a gamer should have played.

Am I really sitting here writing about why Half-Life is good? Yes, I am, but that's because it's so amazingly fantastic, so mind-blowingly good, so unquestionably a masterpiece, that it deserves to have what has already been said about it millions of times said again by me. If there was any doubt in my mind that video games are art, it has been eradicated by this game and it's sequel. This may seem like an odd choice for claiming games are art, but I believe it has the depth, complexity, and emotional attachment that a true work of art has. People latch on to games like Braid as examples of games as art because they outwardly appear to be "artsy" games, with vague plots and symbolism and plenty of emotional torment thrown at you, but once you look deeper a certain amount of pretentiousness is revealed, and you have to question how meaningful such works really are. Half-Life is not pretentious. It is not trying to appear "artsy," because it knows it has enough value to not have to hide behind such a facade to convince the public of it's worth. It may seem silly to reccomend such a famous game because "everyone's played it," but no matter how famous a game is there will always be someone who hasn't played it (I know I have a whole bucket list of essential titles that remain unplayed, such as Final Fantasy VI and Resident Evil 4), and if that person is you, rectify the situation as soon as possible. It remains a staple of any gamer's collection for a reason. Just be careful dismounting ladders. Fall damage is a bitch in this game.

Score: 10/10

Старый-добрый Half-Life, для его прохождения потратил не много - не мало 18 часов, но не сожалею об этом. Игра того стоит, так что всем рекомендую пройти её, а потом, конечно же, пройти и вторую часть данного шедевра. Это 4/5!

FPS 게임의 혁신이라고 말할 수 있는 게임.
하프라이프는 이전까지만 해도 둠 시리즈 같은 무작정 싸움밖에 없었던 FPS의 틀을 파괴했습니다.
그건 바로 지금 봐도 흠 잡을 곳 없는 스토리로 많은 이들에게 찬사를 받았습니다.
지금은 고전 게임의 축에 들고 그래픽이나 물리엔진 등은 매우 허술하지만요.
거기에 한국어 음성은 이 게임을 더 욕보이게 만듭니다.
매우 우꽝스럽고 외국적인 억양으로 발음하는 한국어 음성은 마치 보이스웨어 같습니다.
이 음성은 많은 네티즌들에게 웃음거리가 되고 있죠.
저는 이 게임을 구지 하라고는 안하겠습니다.
다만 구세대의 영광을 느끼고 싶다면 해볼만한 게임 중에 하나일 뿐이죠.

Wer Half Life nicht gespielt hat verpasst einen Meilenstein. Half Life hat Maßstäbe für moderne Shooter gesetzt und ich habe noch nicht einmal die ganzen Mods ausprobiert wovon es auch einige sehr gute geben soll.
Half-Life is an outstanding achievement. It still holds up well today, and even if you do think its aged, you can just get the Black Mesa mod and play though the one of the best shooters ever made.

They say you're not a PC gamer if you haven't played Half Life.

I agree with them...

Legendary FPS game.

Score : 7/10 
(for my first time that I played it in 2001)
Now I know this game isn't as fun as the rest in the series, but it's still a good game to start with for the series

It's Half-life.  It changed narrative style in games forever, and won basically every award possible at the time.  What more can be said? if you have it, you already understand; If you don't have it... GET IT!
You play it, you love it. And that is all. Part of one of the best franchise in gaming to date. This game never gets old no matter how many times I play it. JUST DO IT!
Indimenticabile

Uma das melhores ficções científicas que já vi em minha vida, sério.
Vale muito a pena jogar esse maravilhoso jogo, a história te prende, vc sempre quer saber o que vai acontecer e como vai acabar. 

Sem mais o que falar, mas HL é HL.

Hace falta que diga algo? Todos conocen Half-Life! No será el padre de los FPS, pero si que influenció un montón en el desarrollo de la historia en estos.

La historia de un Físico recibido en el M.I.T que debido a un experimento que salió mal se ve obligado a luchar contra cientos de alienígenas provenientes de otro mundo, con el fin de salvar a sus colegas científicos.

Quizás para el que lo juegue por primera vez no le guste demasiado ya que se notan los años que han pasado desde su lanzamiento, pero creanme, este juego era la puta magia!

This was one of my first ever games and I was hooked from the start. The long ride into the huge Black Mesa complex gives you time to apreciate the scale and ambition Valve were aiming for. And this was long before the dizzying heights of Half Life 2 and its sequel episodes.

Lone scientist Gordon Freeman witnesses the Resonance Cascade first hand, opening the portal to another dimension and stumbling upon events which will rumble on through the series. As Gordon, you are tasked with escaping Black Mesa and destroying the mysterious forces on Xen.

Prepare for unforseen consequences!
Шедевр.
Game good.
the nerds who like this game dont even have a quarter of a life
This game Is the best fps ive ever played
Incredibile difficile pensare a qualcosa meglio riuscita... Epico epico epico.
эту игру должен знать каждый геймер.
Se você não gosta da série Half-Life, eu não gosto de você... você não é boa pessoa! Sai andando sem olhar para trás! :D

09/10 il y a eu un avant et un après Half-life. Un jeu qui a largement contribué à faire basculé les jeux vidéos dans une autres dimensions et LE JEU qui aura révolutionné les FPS jusqu'alors tous simples clones de Doom. Pour l'époque la claque est térrible et même en 2013 ont ne peut encore que constater le travail monstreux qu'a réalisé Valve. Même si le jeu a sacrément vieilli en tout point, il reste étonnament supérieur en interêt, en qualité scénaristique et de contenu que nombres de FPS consoles vulgaires et/ou mou du genoux sorti depuis 15ans. Un bijoux que tout gamer se doit au moins de faire une fois, même si l'excellentissime mod "Black mesa" le rend malheureusement peu attractif pour les moins de 20ans.
